case_vignette: A 33-year-old man presents to the emergency department with altered mental status. He was at work as a construction worker when his coworkers found him down at the work site. The patient recently underwent anesthesia for an appendectomy several months ago. He also has a past medical history of schizophrenia well controlled with haloperidol and is currently taking phenytoin for epilepsy. He is also currently taking propranolol for anxiety and hyperthyroidism. His temperature is 106°F (41.1°C), blood pressure is 109/62 mmHg, pulse is 170/min, respirations are 23/min, and oxygen saturation is 95% on room air. Physical exam is notable for an altered man with a Glasgow Coma Scale of 10. He has minimal muscle tone and is incoherent when answering questions. The patient is covered in sweat and dirt.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Endocrinology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I'm feeling very confused, having a hard time understanding and answering questions, and I'm sweating a lot.
How old are you and what is your sex?
I'm a 33-year-old man.
When did these symptoms start?
They started today while I was at work.
Have you been diagnosed with any medical conditions like diabetes?
I have not been diagnosed with diabetes, but I do have schizophrenia and epilepsy.
Are you currently taking any medications for your schizophrenia or epilepsy?
Yes, I am taking haloperidol for schizophrenia and phenytoin for epilepsy.
Have you eaten anything today? If so, what and when?
The case vignette does not provide information about what or when I have eaten.
Have you experienced shaking, palpitations, or have you had any seizures recently?
The case vignette doesn’t mention shaking or seizures recently, but my pulse is very high.
Have you had a fever or any signs of infection recently?
I have a very high temperature right now.
Have you missed any doses of your medications or taken any new medications or substances?
The case vignette doesn't provide that information.

Given the symptoms of confusion, difficulty understanding and answering questions, excessive sweating, tachycardia, and hyperthermia, along with your current medications – antipsychotic and antiepileptic, a drug-induced cause such as neuroleptic malignant syndrome is a concern. 

**Final Diagnosis:** Neuroleptic malignant syndrome (NMS)

An urgent evaluation is needed.
